column1: This person is credited with coining the term "Artificial Intelligence" for the 1956 Dartmouth Conference.
This pioneer in the field of AI defined it as "artificial intelligence is the science of making machines do things that would require intelligence if done by men."
It is the ability to solve emotional problems such as knowing which emotions are similar or opposites, and how they convey.
column3: What is emotional identification, perception, and expression?
column4: What is emotional facilitation or thought?

column1: Alfred Binet, the inventor of the IQ test, picked these four elements as the "essential ingredients of intelligence".
column2: What are judgement, common sense, initiative, and adaptability?
column3: What are memory, speed, creativity, and knowledge?
column4: What are reasoning, logic, computation, and analysis?
column5: What are emotion, perception, communication, and learning?

column1: This term describes a period in the 1970s when progress in AI research slowed and funding was dramatically reduced.
This test, proposed by Alan Turing, is used to determine if a machine can exhibit intelligent behavior indistinguishable from that of a human.
column5: What is the Common Sense Exam?

column1: This component of a robot is responsible for providing the control signals that activate its various parts for manipulation.
column5: What is the power source unit?

column1: This person proposed eight types of intelligence in the 1980s and 1990s.
It is the first mathematical model of brain neurons in 1943, developed by McCulloh and Pitts.
This law predicts that the speed and memory capacity of computers will double approximately every two years.
